head.title: Top 3Com Officer Adds Storm Technology Post

hedline.hl1: Top 3Com Officer Adds Storm Technology Post

block.p: L. William Krause, who stepped down as president and chief executive of the 3Com Corporation last year but remains chairman, said Wednesday that he had joined Storm Technology Inc., a start-up company involved in color computer-imaging, as president and chief executive.
Storm, based in Mountain View, Calif., is developing image-compression technology for producing high-quality color computer images; it has raised $3 million in venture financing.

L. William Krause, who stepped down as president and chief executive of the 3Com Corporation last year but remains chairman, said Wednesday that he had joined Storm Technology Inc., a start-up company involved in color computer-imaging, as president and chief executive.
Storm, based in Mountain View, Calif., is developing image-compression technology for producing high-quality color computer images; it has raised $3 million in venture financing.

In addition to holding the chairmanship of 3Com, a computer networking company, Mr. Krause, 49, is chairman of the Pensoft Corporation, another start-up company, which is developing software for pen-based computers.

He retired from daily operations at 3Com in September 1990. After spending one semester studying piano, German and statistics at a community college, he returned to work as a venture capitalist and adviser to various Silicon Valley companies.
"I've discovered that I'm too young to retire, and that fundamentally I'm an entrepreneur at heart," Mr. Krause said in a telephone interview. "I still have the passion to build a new company."
He said Storm was at a stage similar to where 3Com was when he joined in 1981. 3Com went on to become a technological leader in building networks of personal computers.

During his tour as a venture capitalist, Mr. Krause said he became convinced that three areas of technology would be significant in the 1990's: global data networks, a focus for 3Com; mobile computing, which he is involved in through Pensoft, and compression technology, which would allow the integration of digital images on desktop computers, Storm's specialty.
"It's an enormous market opportunity," Mr. Krause said. "The number of color pages being produced in the United States is going up exponentially."

Without compression, color images require too much memory capacity for processing on personal computers. Storm's technology can compress color images by a factor of 20 times, so that a typical 4-inch-by-5-inch color photograph that requires 22 million bytes of storage is reduced to 1.1 million bytes.
At Storm, Mr. Krause joins Adriaan Ligtenberg, the company's founder, vice president of engineering and chief technical officer, who developed image-compression technology at Bell Labs.

Before joining 3Com, Mr. Krause spent more than 14 years at the Hewlett-Packard Company, where he was the first computer salesman for the company's Western region. He holds a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering from the Citadel.
